title: Relation to existing literature
text:
The terminology and methods used in weightedstate are consistent with established literature on survival and multistate analysis.
The weighted Kaplan–Meier estimator has been described in various contexts, including inverse-probability weighting for causal inference. Keogh & Van Geloven (2024) discuss the use of weighted Kaplan–Meier after artificial censoring, which is a specific application of the general weighted estimator implemented here. In the single-event setting, the weighted Aalen–Johansen estimator in weightedstate is equivalent to this weighted Kaplan–Meier estimator.
Standard survival analysis texts establish the Aalen–Johansen estimator as the multistate generalization of the Kaplan–Meier estimator. The introduction of weights, as implemented in weightedstate, follows the principles of weighted Nelson–Aalen and product-limit estimators, where weights are incorporated into the risk sets and event counts.

title: survival.weighted_aalen_johansen
text:
survival.weighted_aalen_johansen
survival.weighted_aalen_johansen(times, reals, weights)
Calculates the weighted Aalen-Johansen estimate for time-to-event data.
This function computes the probability of an event occurring over time, with support for weights. It can handle single events (like in Kaplan-Meier), or competing events (like in CIF).
Args: times: A Polars Series containing the event times. reals: A Polars Series containing the event types (0 for censored, 1 for event of interest, 2 for competing event). weights: A Polars Series containing the weights for each observation.
Returns: A Polars DataFrame containing the weighted Aalen-Johansen estimate.

title: Get started
text:
weightedstate implements weighted Aalen–Johansen estimators for time-to-event data. In the single-event setting, this estimator reduces to the weighted Kaplan–Meier estimator.
The package provides a single core function, weighted_aalen_johansen, which supports both single-event survival data and competing risks / multistate settings.
The weights provided to the estimator may be inverse-probability weights and may be time-dependent.

title: Estimation framework
text:
The Aalen–Johansen estimator is a non-parametric method for estimating transition probabilities in a multistate model. It can be expressed as a product-integral of the cumulative hazard increments, which are estimated using a non-parametric equivalent of a Nelson–Aalen estimator.
The introduction of weights into this framework is straightforward. The weighted Aalen–Johansen estimator is calculated in the same way as the unweighted version, but with the risk sets and event counts adjusted by the provided weights. Specifically, at each event time, the number of individuals at risk and the number of events are replaced by the sum of their corresponding weights.

Kaplan–Meier as a special case
The Kaplan–Meier estimator, used for estimating the survival function in single-event survival analysis, is a special case of the Aalen–Johansen estimator. This equivalence holds when the multistate model has only two states: an initial state and an absorbing event state.
When weights are introduced, this relationship is preserved. A weighted Kaplan–Meier estimator is the two-state special case of the weighted Aalen–Johansen estimator.

title: Examples
text:
Single-event setting
This example demonstrates how to use weighted_aalen_johansen to perform a weighted survival estimation. The results coincide with a weighted Kaplan–Meier estimator.
import polars as pl
from weightedstate.survival import weighted_aalen_johansen

times = pl.Series([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
reals = pl.Series([1, 0, 1, 1, 0])
weights = pl.Series([0.5, 1.5, 0.8, 1.2, 0.9])

result = weighted_aalen_johansen(times, reals, weights)
print(result)


Competing risks setting
This example shows how to use the function for a weighted cumulative incidence estimation in a competing risks setting.
import polars as pl
from weightedstate.survival import weighted_aalen_johansen

times = pl.Series([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
reals = pl.Series([1, 0, 1, 2, 0])
weights = pl.Series([0.5, 1.5, 0.8, 1.2, 0.9])

result = weighted_aalen_johansen(times, reals, weights)
print(result)
